comments:
I'm developing a Rich Client Application and want to start it with Java Web Start.
It works fine if I just export it as a product and run the .exe file, but when I want to run it as Web Start, the trouble begins.

I've downloaded the RCP Runtime Binary (http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops/R-3.2-200606291905/download.php?dropFile=eclipse-RCP-3.2-win32.zip)
and I have added the missing plugins from my eclipse 3.2 distribution.

I have made the jnlp files as nessesary and found out, that the problem lies in when I add org.eclipse.update.core_3.2.0.v20060605.jar in my jnlp, the following error occurs:
(When the jar file is not in the directory I just get the error that org.eclipse.update.core is missing as a required bundle)

!SESSION 2006-09-24 22:40:05.130 -----------------------------------------------

!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi 4 0 2006-09-24 22:40:07.113

In the case of Java Web start, java web start itself plays the role of the update.configurator / update manager (it discovers the bundles and OSGi-install them). The error you are encountering is unlikely a result of the update.configurator warning you are seeing.
The error seems to indicate that some bundles used to run your application are missing. Make sure that all the bundles required to run your application are listed in one of the jnlp referred from your main jnlp file, and also check that you specified the property eclipse.product or eclipse.application.
Have you worked around your problem?

No it's still not working.

The thing is, I would like create a standalone RCP application and also as Java webstart.
That's why I have the update manager.

When I export my application from Eclipse, everything works fine.

I take the jarfiles from the export, signs them, and then uses the same configuration files.

I'm running out of ideas :-)

It seems to me that you should try to create multiple features partitioning your plug-ins between the core ones (your app logic and all the plugins you use from RCP), and then have one feature containing just the jnlp file and including the core one and a second feature including all the update related plugins and also including the core feature. This way all you application logic is contained into one place, the core feature, and the specificities about the deployment are isolated.

- Feature Core
    plugin A
    plugin B
    plugin C
    plugin org.eclipse.swt
    etc...

- Feature Standard deployment
    includes Feature Core
    plugin update.core
    plugin update.configurator

- Feature JNLP deployment
    includes Feature Core.
    other plugins if necessary


Does this help?

I've run into this, too, and I notice something interesting.

The path referenced is valid up until the very last folder, "plugins":

C:\Documents and Settings\dmcreynolds.ASTORIA\Application Data\Sun\Java\Deployment\cache\javaws\http\Dbriones\P80\DMief\DMeclipse3.2.1\plugins

On my hard drive, there's a directory called "DMPlugins" that contains my cached jar files.  But it looks like Eclipse is looking for "Plugins"

traces.message: No application id has been found.
